analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā vuttam arahatā iti me suta
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One:

original: “Tathā tathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu upaparikkheyya yathā yathāssa upaparikkhato bahiddhā cassa viññāṇaṁ avikkhittaṁ avisaṭaṁ ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhitaṁ anupādāya na paritasseyya.
analyzed: tathā tathā bhikkhave bhikkhu upaparikkheyya yathā yathā assa upaparikkhataḥ bahiddhā ca ssa viññāṇam a vikkhittam a visaṭam ajjhattam a saṇṭhitam an upādāya na paritasseyya
translated: “Monks, a monk should contemplate in such a way that his consciousness would not be scattered externally or internally. He should not be anxious because of external things. He should not grasp at anything in the world.

original: Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī”ti.
analyzed: bahiddhā bhikkhave viññāṇe a vikkhitte a visaṭe sati ajjhattam a saṇṭhite an upādāya a paritassataḥ āyatim jāti jarā maraṇa dukkha samudaya sambhavaḥ na hoti iti
translated: If his consciousness is not scattered externally or internally, if he is not anxious because of external things, if he does not grasp at anything in the world, then the origin of future birth and death, of the formation and decay of the world, is destroyed.”

analyzed: tattha itam iti vuccati  satta saṅga pahīnassa  netti chinnassa bhikkhuno
translated: And in this connection it was said:🔽“For the monk who has given up the seven attachments,🔽who has cut the tether,
the round of births is exhausted:
for him there is no continuation of existence.”

original: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
analyzed: ayam pi atthaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā iti me sutam ti
translated: This too was the meaning of what was said by the Blessed One, so I have heard.
